questions.text: A 32-year-old male with a history of HIV presents to the clinic complaining of a persistent cough and fever for the past two weeks. His CD4 count is 150 cells/mm³. A chest X-ray reveals diffuse infiltrates, and a sputum culture on Sabouraud dextrose agar shows oval yeast cells within macrophages. He has not traveled outside India. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Histoplasma capsulatum

 

Option A:

 

Histoplasmosis, also known as Darling's disease, is caused by the dimorphic fungus Histoplasma capsulatum. Histoplasmosis is endemic in the central and eastern United States, particularly in areas around the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys, which aligns with the patient not having traveled outside the United States. It has also become increasingly common in India, especially North India.

 

Clinical Manifestations: Most common form is pulmonary histoplasmosis, ranging from mild flu-like illness to chronic cavitary histoplasmosis. Mucocutaneous oral lesions are particularly seen in Indian patients. Disseminated histoplasmosis occurs in individuals with low cell-mediated immunity, like HIV patients.

 

Laboratory Diagnosis:

 

  • Histopathological staining shows tiny oval yeast cells with narrow-based budding.

 

 

  • Culture at 25°C yields mycelial colonies; at 37°C, it converts to yeast form. Antibodies detectable by CFT and immunodiffusion test.

  • Skin tests can indicate delayed-type hypersensitivity.

 

 

Figure: Bone marrow biopsy showing intracellular (inside macrophage) 2-4 μm yeast cells with narrow based budding.

Treatment: 

  • Acute pulmonary and disseminated histoplasmosis: Liposomal amphotericin B.

  • Chronic cavitary pulmonary histoplasmosis: Itraconazole.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Cryptococcus neoformans is a cause of meningitis in HIV patients and would typically be diagnosed with India ink staining of the cerebrospinal fluid, not sputum culture.

 

Option C. Coccidioides immitis could cause similar symptoms but is endemic to the Southwestern United States and parts of Central and South America. It is less likely to show yeast within macrophages on sputum culture.

 

Option D. Pneumocystis jirovecii is also a common opportunistic pathogen in HIV patients but would not grow on Sabouraud dextrose agar and does not present as oval yeast cells within macrophages. It is typically identified by a silver stain of respiratory specimens showing crushed ping pong ball appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The patient’s low CD4 count and symptoms suggest an opportunistic infection. The presence of oval yeast cells within macrophages in the sputum sample, along with diffuse pulmonary infiltrates, is characteristic of Histoplasma capsulatum, especially in an immunocompromised patient.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1e/p563

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with HIV presents to a clinic in Mumbai with a 10-day history of cough. His CD4 count is low, and he has not been on antiretroviral therapy. Sputum culture on Sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA) reveals broad-based budding yeasts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blastomycosis

 

Option B:

 

The sputum culture showing broad-based budding yeasts is characteristic of Blastomyces dermatitidis. Although traditionally not common in India, there have been case reports of blastomycosis in the Indian subcontinent. The broad-based budding is a key feature distinguishing Blastomyces from other fungi.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Histoplasma capsulatum typically shows narrow-based budding and is more associated with intracellular organisms in macrophages.

 

Option C. Coccidioidomycosis is endemic to the Southwestern United States and parts of Central and South America, not India, and would show spherules with endospores in culture.

 

Option D. Paracoccidioidomycosis is endemic to South America and presents with multiple budding yeast cells, showing mickey mouse or pilots wheel appearance which is not described in this case.

 

 

Figure: Paracoccidioidomycosis. A. Schematic representation of mycelial and yeast forms; B. Methenamine silver staining shows yeast from (pilot wheel appearance)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sputum culture showing broad-based budding yeasts is characteristic of Blastomyces dermatitidis.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e, p588

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with advanced HIV presents with a one-month history of progressive dyspnea on exertion, nonproductive cough, and fever. She has not been adherent to antiretroviral therapy and her CD4 count is 50 cells/μL. A chest CT shows bilateral interstitial infiltrates. Bronchoalveolar lavage is performed and silver stain shows cup-shaped organisms. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neumocystis jirovecii

 

Option B:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP) is a common opportunistic infection in patients with severe immunosuppression, especially in those with HIV/AIDS and a CD4 count below 200 cells/μL. The cup-shaped organisms (Ping pong ball appearance) on silver stain of the bronchoalveolar lavage fluid are indicative of PJP.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cryptococcus neoformans typically causes meningitis in immunocompromised patients and would be visualized as encapsulated yeasts in cerebrospinal fluid, not on lung lavage.

 

Option C. Histoplasma capsulatum can cause pulmonary symptoms but would present as intracellular yeast within macrophages on silver staining.

 

Option D. Coccidioides immitis causes pulmonary symptoms and can be seen on silver staining, but it typically forms spherules filled with endospores, not the cup-shaped organisms seen in PJP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia is the most common opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients like in HIV/AIDS esp. If CD4 count is below 200 cells/μL and show cup-shaped organisms (Ping pong ball appearance) on silver stain of bronchoalveolar lavage.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p550, 2/e p574

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with advanced HIV presents with a chronic cough, weight loss, and night sweats. Physical examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. Chest radiography shows a miliary pattern. Bone marrow biopsy is performed, and culture on Sabouraud dextrose agar shows small intracellular yeasts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Histoplasmosis

 

Option A:

 

The clinical presentation is suggestive of a disseminated fungal infection, commonly seen in HIV patients with a low CD4 count. The presence of small intracellular yeasts on bone marrow biopsy and culture is indicative of Histoplasma capsulatum, which can cause a disseminated disease that presents with a miliary pattern on chest radiography and hepatosplenomegaly.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Candida albicans typically causes mucocutaneous infections, such as thrush and esophagitis, rather than disseminated disease with a miliary pattern on chest X-ray.

 

Option C. Cryptococcus neoformans is more commonly associated with meningitis in HIV patients and would be diagnosed with India ink staining of the cerebrospinal fluid, not typically found within macrophages on a bone marrow biopsy.

 

Option D. Sporothrix schenckii causes sporotrichosis, which typically presents as a lymphocutaneous infection following traumatic inoculation with the organism from a contaminated source, not a disseminated lung disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical symptoms suggest Histoplasmosis, especially in HIV patients with low CD4 counts. Key indicators include small intracellular yeasts found in bone marrow biopsies, typical of Histoplasma capsulatum, leading to disseminated disease with miliary patterns on chest X-rays and hepatosplenomegaly. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1st/p563, 2/e p586

questions.text: A 38-year-old HIV-positive patient presents with fever and a productive cough for over a month. He reports significant night sweats and unintentional weight loss. On examination, there are multiple skin lesions ranging from papular to ulcerative. His CD4 count is 85 cells/mm³. Chest radiography reveals patchy infiltrates. Sputum culture on Sabouraud dextrose agar at 25 degrees celsius shows white dense cottony colonies with no pigment on reverse and Calcofluor preparation from those colonies revealed, broad-based budding yeasts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blastomycosis

 

Option C:

The key finding of broad-based budding yeasts in the sputum culture is characteristic of Blastomyces dermatitidis, a dimorphic fungus which can cause chronic pneumonia that mimics tuberculosis and extrapulmonary manifestations such as skin lesions. This presentation is consistent with blastomycosis, especially in an immunocompromised patient with a low CD4 count.

 

 

Figure: Colonies at 25 degrees C- fluffy white mycelium or slowly as glabrous, tan, nonsporulating colonies; Colonies at 37 degrees C- are wrinkled and folded, glabrous and yeast-like; On Microscopy- one-celled, smooth-walled conidia borne on short lateral to terminal hyphal branches

 

 

Figure: Tissue section showing large, broad-base, unipolar budding yeast-like cells of Blastomyces dermatitidis. “Figure of 8” 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Histoplasmosis often presents with a similar clinical picture but would show small intracellular yeasts on culture, not broad-based budding yeasts.

 

Option B. Coccidioidomycosis can present with pulmonary symptoms and skin lesions but typically shows spherules filled with endospores on culture, not broad-based budding yeasts.

 

Option D. Penicillium marneffei infection is endemic to Southeast Asia and presents with fever, anemia, and weight loss, but the organism exhibits a characteristic central septation rather than broad-based budding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blastomyces dermatitidis, a dimorphic fungus which can cause chronic pneumonia that mimics tuberculosis and extrapulmonary manifestations such as skin lesions. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p564

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with advanced HIV presents with unilateral lower extremity swelling and pain, which he first noticed after a recent trip to a rural area in northeastern India. Examination reveals localized warmth and erythema. Doppler ultrasonography confirms deep vein thrombosis. A biopsy of an enlarged inguinal lymph node demonstrates small, budding yeasts within macrophages. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Disseminated histoplasmosis

 

Option A:

 

While Histoplasma capsulatum is not endemic to India, isolated cases have been reported, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. The patient's symptoms, travel history to a rural area, and histopathological findings of small, budding yeasts within macrophages are consistent with disseminated histoplasmosis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Cutaneous candidiasis typically presents with skin and mucous membrane lesions, not deep vein thrombosis and lymphadenopathy.

 

Option C. Cryptococcal infection in HIV-positive patients usually affects the central nervous system, presenting as meningitis.

 

Option D. Mucormycosis, caused by fungi in the order Mucorales, typically involves the sinuses or lungs in immunocompromised patients and does not present with small, budding yeasts within macrophages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histoplasma capsulatum, the causative agent of histoplasmosis, may not be endemic to India, but isolated cases, especially in immunocompromised individuals like those with HIV, have been reported. The presence of small, budding yeasts within macrophages in the lymph node biopsy is characteristic of histoplasmosis. The travel history to a rural area also supports the likelihood of exposure to environments where Histoplasma capsulatum might be present, such as in soil contaminated with bird or bat droppings.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p563, 2/e p586, Jagdish Chander 3/e p212-25

choices.text: It closely mimics tuberculosis in the early stages.
The infectious form is the mycelial form.
Person-to-person transmission occurs via droplet infection.

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV-positive man presents with persistent fever, significant weight loss, and abdominal discomfort. He recently visited the Western Ghats during the monsoon season. Examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory tests show pancytopenia, and a bone marrow biopsy reveals macrophages filled with multiple small budding yeasts. What is the most accurate statement regarding his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The infectious form is the mycelial form.

 

Option C:

 

Histoplasmosis, also known as Darling's disease, is caused by the dimorphic fungus Histoplasma capsulatum, which has three biovars:

 

  • H. capsulatum var. capsulatum: Causes classical histoplasmosis, the most common type.
  • H. capsulatum var. duboisii: Causes African histoplasmosis, often affecting skin and bones.
  • H. capsulatum var. farciminosum: Causes epizootic histoplasmosis in horses and mules.

 

Epidemiology: Endemic in the USA, especially the Ohio and lower Mississippi River valleys. Frequently reported in West Bengal, India, along the Ganga River. 

 

Reservoir: Humid, acidic soil with bird or bat droppings.

 

Transmission: Inhalation of contaminated spores.

 

Clinical Manifestations: Most common form is pulmonary histoplasmosis, ranging from mild flu-like illness to chronic cavitary histoplasmosis. Mucocutaneous oral lesions are particularly seen in Indian patients. Disseminated histoplasmosis occurs in individuals with low cell-mediated immunity, like HIV patients.

 

Laboratory Diagnosis:

 

  • Histopathological staining shows tiny oval yeast cells with narrow-based budding.
  • Culture at 25°C yields mycelial colonies; at 37°C, it converts to yeast form. Antibodies detectable by CFT and immunodiffusion test.
  • Skin tests can indicate delayed-type hypersensitivity.

 

 

Figure: Histoplasma capsulatum. A. 2–4 μm yeast cells with narrow-based budding (Giemsa stain) (arrow showing); B. Mold form, septate thin hyphae with tuberculate macroconidia (arrow showing)

 

Treatment:

 

  • Acute pulmonary and disseminated histoplasmosis: Liposomal amphotericin B.
  • Chronic cavitary pulmonary histoplasmosis: Itraconazole.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While it can present similarly to tuberculosis, this is not a distinguishing feature of the disease itself.

 

Option B. Culture can be diagnostic if it yields the characteristic organism.

 

Option D. Histoplasmosis is not transmitted from person to person but through inhalation of environmental spores.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Despite being uncommon in India, histoplasmosis can occur, especially in immunocompromised individuals such as those with HIV/AIDS. The mycelial form of Histoplasma capsulatum, found in the environment, is the infectious form and can be contracted from soil, particularly in areas with bird and bat droppings, such as the Western Ghats during the monsoon season when fungal growth is abundant.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p563, 2/e p586, Harrison 18/e p1641

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman from Chandigarh with a history of asthma and allergic rhinitis presents with recurrent episodes of rhinitis and nasal blockage for the last two years. On examination, multiple nasal polyps and mucosal thickening are noted. Biopsy and culture of the nasal tissue grow filamentous fungi with dichotomous branching at 45 degrees. Which organism is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aspergillus fumigatus

 

Option A:

 

Aspergillus fumigatus is a common cause of allergic fungal sinusitis, particularly in individuals with asthma and nasal polyposis. The hallmark of Aspergillus infection is the presence of septate hyphae that branch at acute angles, often at 45 degrees, seen in tissue biopsy and culture.

 

 

Figure: On SDA - colonies are typically blue-green with a suede-like surface

 

On LPCB mount- Conidial heads are typically columnar (up to 400 x 50 µm but often much shorter and smaller) and uniseriate. Conidiophore stipes are short, smooth-walled and have conical-shaped terminal vesicles 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Rhizopus, associated with mucormycosis, typically has non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching.

 

Option C. Mucor, also associated with mucormycosis, has similar characteristics to Rhizopus.

 

Option D. Candida does not typically cause allergic fungal sinusitis and presents with pseudohyphae and yeast forms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspergillus fumigatus as the most likely organism responsible for allergic fungal sinusitis in a patient with asthma, allergic rhinitis, nasal polyps, and mucosal thickening, supported by the finding of septate hyphae with dichotomous branching at 45 degrees in biopsy and culture.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p573, 2/e p596-97, Harrison 18/e p1656

questions.text: An HIV-positive individual with a CD4 count of 50 cells/mm³ presents with respiratory distress. A Gram stain of the lung aspirate reveals yeast-like morphology. Which of the following is the least likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aspergillus fumigatus

 

Option D:

 

Aspergillus fumigatus typically appears as septate hyphae rather than yeast forms on Gram stain. The other organisms listed can present with yeast-like forms in clinical specimens.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Candida tropicalis can present as yeast in lung aspirates and can cause infection in HIV patients.

 

Option B. Cryptococcus neoformans is a common cause of fungal infections in HIV-positive individuals, particularly meningitis, but can also present with lung infections.

 

Option C. Penicillium marneffei is a dimorphic fungus endemic in Southeast Asia and can cause infections in HIV-positive patients that may present with yeast-like forms on Gram stain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspergillus fumigatus, known for its filamentous fungal morphology, is the least likely cause of an infection presenting with yeast-like forms in a lung aspirate, particularly in an HIV-positive patient with a low CD4 count. This distinction is important for accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment of fungal infections in immunocompromised patients.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p573, Jagdish Chander 3/e p20, p21, p347, Ananthanarayan 8/e p607, p613, 610

questions.text: A 42-year-old farmer from a rural area near Bhopal presents to an ophthalmologist with redness, pain, and decreased vision in one eye. He reports that symptoms started after harvesting crops. Corneal scraping reveals narrow angled septate hyphae. Which of the following is the likely etiologic agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspergillus

 

Option B:

 

Mycotic Corneal Ulcer - Antibiotics suppress the commensal bacteria in eyes and steroid suppresses immune system favoring fungi which are usually saprophytes to cause ocular infections. Commonly responsible agents are Aspergillus, Candida and Fusarium.  Less common agents include Penicillium, Rhizopus, and Mucor

 

Modes of infection: Fungi enter the eyes through ocular injury by vegetative material such as leaf, branch of a tree; common among field workers during harvesting season.

Secondary fungal ulcers are common in patients who are immunosuppressed

 

Clinical features: Symptoms are similar to the bacterial corneal ulcer, but in general mycotic ulcers are less marked and the overall course is slow in progress compared to bacterial keratitis.

 

Treatment –

 

Topical antifungal eye drops - natamycin, amphotericin B and azoles (e.g. fluconalzole, or voriconazole) are used. 

 

Systemic antifungal drugs (e.g. fluconazole or ketoconazole or voriconazole) for severe cases of deeper fungal keratitis

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mucor species, involved in mucormycosis, typically present with broader, ribbon-like, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching.

 

Option C. Histoplasma, a dimorphic fungus, does not typically cause keratitis and is not characterized by septate hyphae in tissue.

 

Option C. Candida may cause keratitis but usually presents with pseudohyphae and yeast cells, not septate hyphae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspergillus species, particularly Aspergillus fumigatus, are known to cause keratitis with narrow-angled septate hyphae seen on corneal scrapings. This condition is often associated with exposure to vegetative matter, consistent with the patient's history of farming.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p573, 2/e p596-97, Jagdish Chander 3/e p401

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus presents to an ophthalmology clinic in Hyderabad with unilateral proptosis, periorbital pain, and visual disturbances. He has a history of recent sinusitis that was treated with antibiotics. Examination reveals ptosis and ophthalmoplegia on the affected side. A biopsy from the nasal sinus shows broad, non-septate hyphae branching at right angles. Which of the following fungi is the most common cause of orbital cellulitis in diabetic patients?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mucor

 

Option A:

 

The patient's clinical presentation and the histopathological finding of broad, non-septate hyphae branching at right angles are characteristic of mucormycosis, caused by fungi in the order Mucorales, such as Mucor. Rhinocerebral mucormycosis commonly seen in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis. It is the most common form; starts as eye and facial pain, may progress to cause orbital cellulitis, proptosis and vision loss

 

 

Figure: Sporangia, columella and sporangiospores of Mucor spp.

 

 

 

Figure: Black-white wooly colonies of Mucor sp. know n as “lid lifters”

Differential diagnosis Aspergillus

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Aspergillus species typically cause a more chronic form of sinusitis and orbital involvement and are characterized by septate hyphae that branch at acute angles.

 

Option C. Candida species are not typically associated with invasive sinus and orbital infections in diabetic patients.

 

Option D. Cryptococcus is more commonly associated with central nervous system infections, particularly meningitis in immunocompromised patients, and would not present with the described histopathological findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucormycosis as the cause of orbital cellulitis in a diabetic patient based on clinical presentation and characteristic histopathological features.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med.Microbiology, 2/e p594.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male from Delhi with a history of untreated HIV presents to the clinic with a two-week history of headache, fever, and neck stiffness. On examination, he is found to have photophobia and a positive Brudzinski's sign. A lumbar puncture is performed, and the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shows an elevated protein level with a low glucose concentration. India has a high prevalence of tuberculosis; however, fungal infections are also considered in differential diagnosis due to his immunocompromised state. Which of the following tests would most likely identify the causative agent in this patient's CSF?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) India ink preparation

 

Option B:

 

India ink preparation is used to visualize Cryptococcus neoformans, a fungus that can cause meningitis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals such as those with HIV/AIDS. The test takes advantage of the organism's thick polysaccharide capsule, which does not take up the ink, resulting in a clear halo around the yeast cells.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ziehl-Neelsen stain: This is typically used to identify acid-fast bacilli, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and would not be appropriate for detecting Cryptococcus in CSF.

 

Option C. Gram stain: While Gram stain can identify a variety of bacteria, it is not the best choice for fungi as the thick capsule of Cryptococcus may resist staining.

 

Option D. KOH preparation: Potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation is used for detecting fungal elements in skin, nails, and hair but is not the optimal choice for visualizing Cryptococcus in CSF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate diagnostic tests for identifying infectious agents in the CSF of an immunocompromised patient. India ink preparation is a specific test for Cryptococcus neoformans, which is a common cause of meningitis in HIV/AIDS patients. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p569, 2/e p593, Ananthanarayan 9/e p613

questions.text: In a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis, a condition that predisposes to certain fungal infections due to altered phagocytic function, which organism is most likely to cause orbital cellulitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mucor

 

Option C:

 

In the context of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), patients are particularly susceptible to mucormycosis, caused by fungi from the Mucorales order, including Mucor. DKA creates an environment with high serum glucose levels and acidic conditions, which impairs neutrophil function. This immune dysfunction makes patients more vulnerable to opportunistic fungal infections like mucormycosis. Mucormycosis can manifest as a serious infection like orbital cellulitis, a condition where the infection spreads to the eye socket. This is a medical emergency and requires prompt treatment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cryptococcus is more commonly associated with central nervous system infections, particularly meningitis in immunocompromised patients, and would not present with the described histopathological findings.

 

Option B. Candida species are not typically associated with invasive sinus and orbital infections in diabetic patients.

 

Option D. Aspergillus species typically cause a more chronic form of sinusitis and orbital involvement and are characterized by septate hyphae that branch at acute angles.

 

Educational Objective:

In diabetic ketoacidosis, the high serum glucose levels and acidic environment impair neutrophil function, making patients particularly susceptible to mucormycosis.

 

Ref: Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p570, 2/e p594

questions.text: A diabetic patient in India presents with a soft tissue infection characterized by the presence of broad, non-septate hyphae on microscopic examination. Which of the following fungi is most likely responsible for this infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Apophysomyces

 

Option D:

 

Apophysomyces, along with other members of the Mucorales order, is characterized by its broad, ribbon-like, non-septate hyphae. This type of fungus is known to cause mucormycosis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with uncontrolled diabetes. Mucormycosis is a serious infection that often affects the sinuses, brain, or lungs, but can also manifest in soft tissue infections. The distinct microscopic features of broad, non-septate hyphae are key in identifying Apophysomyces as the causative agent in this case.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Candida: Typically forms pseudohyphae and yeast cells, not broad, non-septate hyphae.

 

 

 

Option B. Aspergillus: Typically has septate hyphae with acute angle branching, not broad, non-septate hyphae.

 

 

Figure: Conidiation of various Aspergillus species. A)  A. fumigatus; B)  A. flavus; C)  A. niger

 

Option C. Penicillium: Not typically associated with invasive infections in humans and has septate hyphae with characteristic conidia.

 

 

Figure: Penicillium species. A. Colonies on SDA; B. Microscopic picture (LPCB mount); C. Schematic microscopic picture

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apophysomyces, along with other members of the Mucorales order, is characterized by broad, ribbon-like, non-septate hyphae. It is an emerging pathogen causing mucormycosis, especially in immunocompromised individuals such as those with uncontrolled diabetes.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p570-71, 2/e p594

questions.text: Which of the following is a known aseptate fungus that can cause serious infections in immunocompromised patients, such as those with poorly controlled diabetes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rhizopus

 

Option D:

 

Rhizopus species, belonging to the Mucorales order, are aseptate fungi known to cause mucormycosis. This type of infection is particularly severe in immunocompromised individuals, including those with poorly controlled diabetes or diabetic ketoacidosis. Mucormycosis caused by Rhizopus can manifest in various forms, such as rhino-orbital-cerebral, pulmonary, and cutaneous infections. The lack of septation in these fungal hyphae is a distinguishing microscopic feature, aiding in the diagnosis of infections caused by Rhizopus.

 

 

Figure: A. Rhizopus colony on SDA shows white cottony woolly colonies with black spores (salt and pepper appearance); B. Mucor on SDA—white cottony woolly colonies; C. LPCB mount of colonies of Rhizopus shows sporangium with rhizoid present; D. LPCB mount of colonies of Mucor shows sporangium with rhizoid absent

 

 

Figure: Microscopic schematic diagram. A. Rhizopus; B. Lichtheimia; C. Mucor

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aspergillus: This fungus is septate and is not in the category of aseptate fungi.

 

Option B. Candida: While it can cause infections in diabetic patients, it is not aseptate.

 

Option C. Nocardia: It is a bacteria, not a fungus, and it has filamentous, branching, partially acid-fast hyphae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhizopus species, which are part of the Mucorales order, are aseptate fungi that can cause mucormycosis, a severe infection often occurring in diabetic patients, particularly those with ketoacidosis.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p570-71, 2/e p594, Jagdish Chander 3/e p362, Ananthanarayan 9/e p610, 8/e p601-02

choices.text: The nose is a common site of infection.
Diabetes is a common predisposing factor.
The condition is common in India.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman from Bengaluru presents with sinus pain, fever, and a black necrotic eschar on her nasal mucosa. She has poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. Based on the increased incidence in India, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above.

 

Option D:

 

This patient is likely suffering from mucormycosis, a fungal infection caused by Mucorales fungi, which is known to affect the nasal and sinus regions, particularly in diabetic patients, and has a noted prevalence in India.

 

  • Rhinocerebral zygomycosis is the most common and fulminant type of zygomycosis, affecting nose, paranasal sinuses, orbit and palate.
  • Risk factor- MC is Diabetes followed by patient on dialysis, iron overload and Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation
  • Mucormycosis is increasingly recognized in recently developed countries, such as India, mainly in patients with uncontrolled diabetes or trauma

 

Educational Objective:

 

The patient's diabetes and geographic location (India), along with her symptoms (sinus pain and black necrotic eschar), point towards a diagnosis of mucormycosis, which is more prevalent in India and commonly affects the nasal area in diabetic patients.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p570-71, 2/e p594

choices.text: ARDS with widespread hyaline membrane formation
Interstitial pneumonitis with foamy intra-alveolar exudates

questions.text: A 40-year-old individual with HIV/AIDS from Mumbai presents with shortness of breath and a non-productive cough. A chest X-ray reveals diffuse interstitial infiltrates. Considering the patient's immunocompromised status, which morphological appearance of a fungal infection is most consistent with these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Interstitial pneumonitis with foamy intra-alveolar exudates

 

Option C:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP) is common in patients with HIV/AIDS and presents with interstitial pneumonitis characterized by foamy intra-alveolar exudates on histopathological examination.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hemorrhagic and necrotizing pneumonia: This type of pneumonia is often caused by bacterial infections, particularly by aggressive pathogens like certain strains of Staphylococcus aureus or Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It is characterized by the destruction of lung tissue and bleeding into the alveoli and is not typically seen with Pneumocystis jirovecii infection.

 

Option B. ARDS with widespread hyaline membrane formation: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a severe, diffuse inflammatory response in the lungs that leads to acute onset of respiratory failure. It can be caused by various factors, including severe infections, trauma, or inhalation injuries. The hyaline membranes are a hallmark of ARDS, representing protein-rich edema fluid and cellular debris within alveoli. Although patients with Pneumocystis pneumonia can develop ARDS, this is a complication rather than a direct morphological characteristic of the organism itself.

 

Option D. Bronchopulmonary abscess formation: Abscesses in the lung are localized collections of pus within lung tissue, often caused by bacterial infections, particularly in the setting of aspiration pneumonia. They are characterized by a necrotic center surrounded by inflammatory cells and are not typical of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, which does not commonly cause localized suppuration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristics of Pneumocystis jirovecii infection - the presence of interstitial pneumonitis with foamy intra-alveolar exudates, especially those who are immunocompromised.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p576, 2/e p600, Harrison 19/e p1359

questions.text: In the context of a microbial taxonomy lecture in New Delhi, a professor asks the students to identify the organism classified as a fungus. Which of the following is correctly classified as such?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pneumocystis jirovecii

 

Option C:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii is correctly classified as a fungus. It was historically considered to be a protozoan due to its morphology and clinical presentation, but later genetic studies revealed that it is more closely related to fungi. Pneumocystis jirovecii is known for causing Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP), particularly in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Klebsiella: This is a genus of bacteria, known for causing a range of infections including pneumonia and urinary tract infections. It is not a fungus.

 

Option B. Clostridia: This is a genus of bacteria, which includes species such as Clostridium difficile, known for causing severe colitis, and Clostridium botulinum, known for causing botulism. It is also not a fungus.

 

Option D. Listeria: Listeria monocytogenes is a bacterium that can cause listeriosis, a serious infection usually caused by eating food contaminated with the bacterium. Again, it is not a fungus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii is a yeast-like fungus that can cause pneumonia, particularly in immunocompromised hosts.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p576, 2/e p600, Harrison 18/e

1673

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male from a rural area in Punjab presents with decreased vision in the left eye after sustaining trauma while working in the fields. Examination reveals an ulcerative corneal lesion with soft creamy infiltrates. Microscopic examination of a corneal scraping shows sickle-shaped macro conidia and branching aseptate hyphae. 

 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fusarium

 

Option A:

 

The presence of sickle-shaped macro conidia suggests a Fusarium species, which is a common cause of fungal keratitis, especially following trauma with vegetative matter.

 

 

Figure: Fusarium species (LPCB mount)

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Aspergillus: This genus of fungi is known to cause a variety of diseases, most notably pulmonary aspergillosis. However, Aspergillus species typically produce septate hyphae and conidial heads, which were not described in the scenario.

 

Option C. Mucormycosis: While aseptate hyphae are a characteristic of mucormycosis, the presence of sickle-shaped macro conidia described in the patient's sample is not typical for this disease, making this option less likely.

 

Option D. Dermatophytes: These are fungi that cause skin diseases known as dermatophytosis. They typically infect keratinized tissues such as skin, hair, and nails and are not associated with corneal infections. The presence of macro conidia in the shape described does not fit with dermatophytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fusarium is a saprophyte; rarely causes human infections.

 

  •  In immunocompetent individuals, they cause: Keratitis in contact lens wearers and Onychomycosis
  •  In immunocompromised patients: They are angioinvasive and cause pulmonary and sinus infection.
  •  In neutropenic patients and with hematologic malignancies: Disseminated fusariosis occurs with frequent skin lesions.

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p576, 2/e p600

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman from Chennai with a CD4 count of 50 cells/mm³ presents with a dry cough and dyspnea. A chest CT scan shows ground-glass opacities. Bronchoalveolar lavage is performed. What is the drug of choice for the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cotrimoxazole

 

Option A:

 

The patient's symptoms and CD4 count are suggestive of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP), for which cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) is the treatment of choice.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Penicillin: This antibiotic is used against bacterial infections and has no activity against fungi like Pneumocystis jirovecii.

 

Option C. Amphotericin B: While amphotericin B is an antifungal agent, it is not the first-line treatment for Pneumocystis pneumonia. It may be used in severe cases or when patients cannot tolerate cotrimoxazole.

 

Option D. Clotrimazole: This is an antifungal medication commonly used for treating fungal infections of the skin, mouth, and vagina, not for systemic infections like Pneumocystis pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia in an HIV/AIDS patient with severe immunosuppression - cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) is the first-line treatment.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p 576, 2/e p601

choices.text: It is seen only in immunocompromised individuals.
May be associated with pneumatocele formation.

questions.text: In a tertiary care hospital in Kolkata, a clinician is reviewing a presentation on Pneumocystis jirovecii. Which of the following statements about P. jirovecii is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is seen only in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option A:

 

While P. jirovecii is most common in immunocompromised individuals, it can occasionally be identified in those who are immunocompetent, making statement a false.

Pneumocystis is classified under fungus based on nucleic acid sequence studies:

 

  • Exist in two forms: In environment cysts are found, whereas in human tissues both cysts and trophozoites are found.

  • Cysts are inhaled, carried to the lungs, transformed into trophozoite stage which induces an inflammatory response that leads to recruitment of plasma cells resulting in formation of frothy exudate filling the alveoli. Hence, PcP is also called plasma cell pneumonia.

 

Laboratory Diagnosis:

 

Gomori’s methenamine silver (GMS) staining is the method of choice to demonstrate the cysts of P. jirovecii. The cysts resemble black colored crushed ping-pong balls, against the green background.

 

 

Figure: Cysts of Pneumocystis jirovecii in lung tissue of an AIDS patient (methenamine silver stain) (arrow showing)

 

Treatment: Cotrimoxazole is the DOC for Pneumocystis pneumonia. It is also the recommended drug for primary and secondary prophylaxis in patients with HIV.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Frequently associated with CMV (Cytomegalovirus): Pneumocystis jirovecii infection may coexist with other opportunistic infections in immunocompromised patients, including CMV. 

 

Option C. May be associated with pneumatocele formation: Pneumocystis jirovecii can cause pneumatoceles, which are cystic air spaces that develop in the lung due to the damage caused by the infection. This statement is true and describes one of the possible complications of P. jirovecii pneumonia.

 

Option D. Diagnosed with BAL microscopy: Pneumocystis jirovecii can indeed be diagnosed using induced sputum or BAL microscopy, particularly using special stains such as Gomori methenamine silver or immunofluorescence assays, which can detect the cysts or trophic forms of the organism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The objective is to correct the misconception that Pneumocystis jirovecii is only seen in immunocompromised individuals. While P. jirovecii is a significant cause of pneumonia in the immunocompromised, it can also colonize the lungs of healthy individuals without causing illness. This understanding is important for accurate diagnosis and treatment of Pneumocystis pneumonia, especially in patients with weakened immune systems.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p576, 2/e p600
